section.heading: Proof of Concept Definitions and Procedures.

para.text: “Proof of concept” means a test, evaluation, demonstration, or pilot project of a good, service, or technology in a real–world environment to evaluate whether the good, service, or technology can be successfully deployed and is beneficial to the State, in accordance with State Finance and Procurement Article, §13-116(A), Annotated Cod of Maryland.

A “Competitive Proof of Concept Procurement” means a formal competitive procurement method that may be used to solicit proposals for the conduct of a proof of concept prior to full implementation when the head of a unit determines the process to be appropriate and in the best interests of the unit, including:
Testing software–as–a–service or off–the–shelf software;
Testing new, innovative products or services; or
Testing a product or service conceptualized or conceived of by a unit of State government, in accordance State Finance and Procurement Article, §13-116(B)(1), Annotated Code of Maryland.

After obtaining the approval of the head of the procurement agency and before conducting a competitive proof of concept procurement, the procuring unit shall obtain approval from the Secretary of Information Technology, or the Secretary’s Designee.
The Secretary of Information Technology may grant approval for a competitive proof of concept procurement if the procuring unit:
Has sufficient internal resources to manage the proof of concept, including human capital, subject matter expertise, and technological infrastructure, or has the means to obtain these resources; and

Enters into a memorandum of understanding with the Department of Information Technology that requires regular status updates, vendor capacity, and any other information necessary for the Department of Information Technology to evaluate whether the proof of concept can be successfully deployed and is beneficial to the State.
A competitive proof of concept procurement:
May be conducted through the issuance of a solicitation by any method of procurement authorized under COMAR 21.05.01.01; and
Shall include a statement of the following:
The scope of work or project description, including
The intended use;
Quantity;
Estimated time frame for the proof of concept; and
Anticipated number of proof of concept awards that will be made;
The factors, including price, that will be used in evaluating proposals and the relative importance of each.

A competitive proof of concept procurement solicitation may be distributed to vendors known to offer goods or services within the scope of the proof of concept and shall, except for procurements less than $15,000 not otherwise required by law to be posted, be posted on eMaryland Marketplace Advantage.
After receipt of proposals but before award of a procurement contract, a unit may:
Conduct discussions with an offeror to ensure full understanding of
The requirements of the unit, as set forth in the request for proposals; and
The proposal submitted by the offeror; and
Request product samples for testing by the unit or a demonstration of a product or service and use these samples or demonstrations in its evaluation process.
A request for product samples for testing or demonstration made under §A(2) of this regulation shall be issued to all offerors deemed reasonable at the time of the request.

section.heading: Proof of Concept Award.
section.text: A unit may award one or more of the proposals a contract for the proof of concept.

annotations.annotation: State Finance and Procurement Article, §§12-101, 13-102, 13-116, and 14-303, Annotated Code of Maryland
